housing_context.zoning_regulations: Generally permissive historically. 2023 legislation limiting local authority to restrict growth controversial. Resort towns trying to require workforce housing

major_events: 2011-2013: Post-recession recovery slow, agriculture struggles, tourism growth
2014-2016: Energy sector volatility, Medicaid expansion (2015), housing affordable
2017-2019: Strong economy, tourism boom, housing prices start rising, wildfires increasing
2020-2023: COVID migration boom, housing crisis, recreational marijuana (2020), unprecedented population growth, wildfire seasons severe, polarization increases
historical_context.economic_shocks: Coal industry decline long-term. Oil price volatility. 2020-2023 housing explosion. Wildfires affecting tourism and property
historical_context.natural_disasters: Wildfires increasing frequency and severity (2017-2023). Drought periods. Flooding events. Extreme cold snaps
historical_context.industry_transitions: Coal mining declining. Renewable energy (wind) growing. Tourism eclipsing extractive industries. Remote work creating service economy. Agriculture consolidating
historical_context.political_transitions: Republican dominance solidified. Democratic Governors Bullock (2013-2021) then Gianforte (R 2021-present). Legislature solidly Republican. Libertarian streak vs. growth management tension

comparative_context.national_benchmarks: Below median income. Fastest housing cost increases 2020-2023. Low population density. High public land percentage (federal). Near average educational attainment. Healthcare access challenges in rural areas
comparative_context.unique_factors: Largest population influx rate 2020-2023. Geography (mountains/plains) defines regions. Public lands dominance (30% federal). Native American reservations significant. Extractive industry legacy. Outdoor recreation economy. 'last best place' mystique driving migration. Housing crisis severity unique for rural state
comparative_context.data_considerations: East/West divide (mountains vs. plains). Tribal lands distinct economy and demographics. Extreme recent migration changing profiles. Short-term rentals distorting housing data. Seasonal tourism employment. Small overall population means volatility in statistics. Bozeman/Missoula not representative of state

economic_profile.economic_trends: Steady modest growth 2011-2023. Agriculture dominant but volatile (weather, commodity prices). Food processing major employer. Omaha insurance/financial center. Low unemployment. Recession-resistant economy
economic_profile.income_characteristics: Near national median (~$71k). Omaha metro higher. Low cost of living significantly improves purchasing power. Low unemployment (historically ~3%). Wage growth moderate but steady
economic_profile.economic_resilience: Strong resilience. Diversified economy. Agriculture volatility buffered by processing/services. Minimal 2008 recession impact. Pandemic: essential food industry kept working

demographic_profile.population_trends: Slow steady growth ~0.6% annually 2011-2023. Growth concentrated in Omaha-Lincoln corridor. Rural declining
demographic_profile.migration_patterns: Modest net in-migration. Attracts from Iowa, Kansas; loses some to Colorado, Texas. International immigration important (Latino, African refugees). Intrastate: rural to Omaha-Lincoln
demographic_profile.age_distribution: Slightly younger than national average due to immigration and universities. Rural areas aging. Omaha-Lincoln younger professionals
demographic_profile.diversity_trends: ~78% White, ~11% Latino (growing, especially meatpacking towns), ~5.2% Black, ~2.7% Asian, ~1.5% Native American. Becoming more diverse, especially Omaha and meatpacking towns (Lexington, Grand Island, South Sioux City)
demographic_profile.education_levels: Near national average bachelor's degrees (~33%). University of Nebraska system anchor. Omaha and Lincoln higher attainment. Rural lower
demographic_profile.urbanization: ~73% urban (Omaha metro, Lincoln). 27% rural - agriculture, small towns declining population

political_context.policy_environment: Conservative Republican governance. Unicameral nonpartisan legislature unique nationally. Fiscally conservative, socially conservative. Pro-agriculture policies dominant. Low taxes priority
key_legislation: 2011-2013: Property tax relief efforts, budget discipline
2014-2016: Tax reforms, Medicaid expansion rejected
2017-2019: Property tax debates continue, death penalty abolished then restored (2015-2016 saga)
2020: Medicaid expansion approved by voters (implemented 2020) after legislature resistance
2021-2023: Abortion restrictions, property tax relief, education funding debates, marijuana debates
political_context.housing_policy: Minimal state intervention. Local control. No rent control. Market-based approach. Some affordable housing incentives
political_context.labor_policy: Right-to-work state. $12 minimum wage (2024, from $9 in 2022 - voter-approved increase). Limited worker protections. Agriculture exemptions common
political_context.social_programs: Medicaid expansion approved by voters 2020 despite legislature opposition. Otherwise limited social safety net. Strong private charity/community support tradition
political_context.regulatory_environment: Light regulation. Business-friendly. Agricultural regulations focus. Environmental regulations moderate

regional_characteristics.geography: Great Plains. Sandhills (unique grass-stabilized dunes). Platte River valley. Flat to gently rolling. Vast agricultural lands
regional_characteristics.climate: Continental. Cold winters, hot summers. Tornadoes. Drought risk. Hail. Wide temperature swings. Low precipitation
regional_characteristics.urban_rural_mix: 73% urban (Omaha metro, Lincoln). 27% rural - agriculture dominates landscape. Small towns throughout
regional_characteristics.infrastructure: Good highway system (I-80 corridor). Rail hub (Union Pacific HQ). Eppley Airfield (Omaha). Rural broadband expanding. Ogallala Aquifer critical for agriculture
regional_characteristics.natural_resources: Agricultural land (prime soil), Ogallala Aquifer water, cattle, corn, soybeans, limited oil and gas

housing_context.market_characteristics: Affordable - Omaha median ~$260k, Lincoln ~$280k (2023). Rural very affordable. Among most affordable metros nationally
housing_context.affordability_trends: Slow steady increases 2011-2019. Pandemic increase 2020-2022 but less than national average. Still very affordable
housing_context.construction_trends: Steady construction in Omaha-Lincoln suburbs. Limited rural construction. Single-family dominant. Some multifamily in cities
housing_context.rental_market: ~31% renters. Omaha-Lincoln balanced rental markets. Rural limited rental stock. University towns (Lincoln) tight during school year
housing_challenges: Rural housing stock aging and declining value
Limited rental options in small towns
Minor affordability pressure in Omaha post-pandemic
housing_context.zoning_regulations: Generally permissive. Omaha and Lincoln standard suburban zoning. Rural minimal regulation. Property rights emphasis

major_events: 2011-2013: Recovery from recession (minimal impact), agriculture strong, Keystone XL pipeline debates begin
2014-2016: Death penalty abolished (2015) then restored by voters (2016), agriculture volatility, Medicaid expansion rejected
2017-2019: Agriculture trade war impacts (China tariffs), strong Omaha economy, population growth continues
2020-2023: Medicaid expansion approved by voters (2020), COVID-19 (meatpacking outbreaks), housing price increases, minimum wage increase approved by voters (2022)
historical_context.economic_shocks: China trade war tariffs (2018-2019) impacted agriculture. COVID-19 meatpacking plant outbreaks. Periodic drought impacts. 2019 flooding severe
historical_context.natural_disasters: Tornadoes frequent. 2019 flooding catastrophic in eastern NE. Drought periods (2012). Blizzards. Derecho (2020)
historical_context.industry_transitions: Agriculture consolidation and mechanization. Meatpacking automation increasing. Retail decline. Insurance/financial services growth. Technology sector emerging in Omaha
historical_context.political_transitions: Solid Republican dominance maintained 2011-2023. Unicameral legislature more moderate than other red states. Voter initiatives challenging legislature (Medicaid, minimum wage, death penalty)

comparative_context.national_benchmarks: Near median income but significantly lower cost of living. Low unemployment. Affordable housing. Average educational attainment. Good fiscal health. Low poverty relative to income
comparative_context.unique_factors: Unicameral nonpartisan legislature unique in US. Omaha insurance/financial center. Union Pacific headquarters. Meatpacking industry concentration. Berkshire Hathaway headquarters. Split electoral vote system (congressional district method). Ogallala Aquifer dependence. Strong work ethic culture. Low unemployment even in downturns
comparative_context.data_considerations: Omaha-Lincoln vs. rural divide. Meatpacking towns (Grand Island, Lexington) have unique Latino demographics. Seasonal agriculture affects employment. University of Nebraska enrollment affects Lincoln. Small towns declining. Overall population small so some volatility in statistics

economic_profile.economic_trends: Boom-bust cycles. Devastated by 2008 housing crash. Recovery 2011-2019 strong (Las Vegas). Gaming/tourism dominant but volatile. Tesla (2014) diversification. Pandemic crashed tourism 2020, strong recovery 2021-2023. Lithium mining emerging
economic_profile.income_characteristics: Near national median (~$71k) but extreme inequality. High-earning professionals and casino workers. No state income tax attracts high earners. Cost of living rising
major_employers: Casino/resort companies (MGM, Caesars, Wynn, Las Vegas Sands)
economic_profile.economic_resilience: Highly volatile. 2008 crash worst in nation. Recovery strong but slow. Pandemic devastated tourism 2020. Rapid rebound 2021-2023. Diversification efforts (Tesla, tech) helping

demographic_profile.population_trends: Rapid growth 2011-2019 (~1.6% annually), slowdown 2020-2021, resumed growth 2022-2023. Fastest-growing state in many years
demographic_profile.migration_patterns: Strong in-migration from California (housing costs), Arizona, Texas. International immigration (Latino, Asian). 87% of population in Las Vegas/Reno metros. Remote workers during pandemic
demographic_profile.age_distribution: Younger than national average due to in-migration and entertainment industry. Growing retiree population. Service workers tend younger
demographic_profile.diversity_trends: Minority-majority state: ~48% White, ~30% Latino, ~10% Asian, ~10% Black. Highly diverse, especially Las Vegas. Rapid Latino population growth
demographic_profile.education_levels: Below national average bachelor's degrees (~26%). UNLV, UNR growing. Service industry not requiring degrees. Educational attainment improving but still low
demographic_profile.urbanization: 94% urban - highest in nation. 73% in Las Vegas metro, 16% Reno metro. Vast rural areas nearly empty

political_context.policy_environment: Purple/swing state trending Democratic. Pro-business (no corporate income tax). Gaming industry political influence enormous. Libertarian streak. Labor unions strong (Culinary)
key_legislation: 2011-2013: Education reforms, tax structure debates, Tesla negotiations begin
2014: Tesla Gigafactory tax incentives approved (transformative)
2017-2019: Background checks for gun sales (2016 voter initiative), recreational marijuana (2017), education funding increase
2020: Vote-by-mail permanent, criminal justice reforms
2021-2023: Abortion rights protections, renewable energy mandates, housing initiatives, lithium mining debates
political_context.housing_policy: Limited intervention. Las Vegas market-driven. Recent tenant protections (eviction reforms). Affordable housing incentives. Rapid growth makes planning difficult
political_context.labor_policy: No state income tax. Federal minimum wage $7.25 but many localities higher. Strong Culinary Union in Las Vegas. Right-to-work state but union-friendly in practice (gaming)
political_context.social_programs: Medicaid expansion (2013). Limited social safety net otherwise. Education underfunding chronic issue (ranked near bottom nationally)
political_context.regulatory_environment: Light regulation except gaming (highly regulated). Environmental regulations minimal. Business-friendly

regional_characteristics.geography: Basin and Range - valleys and mountains. Mojave Desert (south), Great Basin Desert (north). Lake Tahoe, Lake Mead. 86% federal land
regional_characteristics.climate: Desert - hot dry summers, mild winters in south, cold winters in north. Very low precipitation. Water scarcity critical issue
regional_characteristics.urban_rural_mix: 94% urban (Las Vegas 73%, Reno 16%, Henderson 8%). 6% rural - vast empty desert and mountains. Mining towns
regional_characteristics.infrastructure: Excellent in Las Vegas (McCarran Airport, I-15 corridor). Reno growing. Rural minimal. Water infrastructure crisis (Lake Mead). Colorado River allocation critical
regional_characteristics.natural_resources: Gold (#1 gold-producing state), silver, copper, lithium (emerging), geothermal energy, sunshine (solar potential), tourism (natural beauty)

housing_context.market_characteristics: High-cost and volatile. Las Vegas median ~$450k (2023), Reno ~$500k. Among worst housing crashes 2008-2011, among strongest recoveries. Extreme boom-bust
housing_context.affordability_trends: Crash 2008-2011 (foreclosures epidemic), recovery 2012-2019, explosion 2020-2023. Prices exceeded 2007 peak. Affordability crisis now
housing_context.construction_trends: Boom-bust cycles. Overbuilt 2005-2007, crash. Resumed 2012, strong 2015-2023. Cannot keep pace with demand. Sprawl continues in desert
housing_context.rental_market: ~44% renters. Tight market. Rents doubled 2019-2023 in many areas. Corporate landlords significant presence
housing_context.zoning_regulations: Permissive to encourage growth. Las Vegas annexation and sprawl. Water availability becoming constraint. Recent efforts to encourage density vs. historical sprawl

major_events: 2011-2013: Worst foreclosure crisis in nation, slow recovery begins, diversification efforts (Tesla recruitment)
2014-2016: Tesla Gigafactory groundbreaking (2014), economic recovery strengthens, Las Vegas Strip projects resume, recreational marijuana approved (2016)
2017-2019: Route 91 Harvest shooting (2017), continued growth, housing prices recover to pre-crash levels, marijuana sales begin
2020-2023: COVID devastates tourism (casinos closed spring 2020), rapid recovery 2021-2023, housing explosion, Raiders NFL team, Formula 1 Grand Prix (2023)
historical_context.economic_shocks: 2008-2012 housing crash and foreclosure crisis (worst in nation). 2017 Route 91 shooting. 2020 casino closures (COVID). Water shortage concerns ongoing
historical_context.natural_disasters: Drought and water shortage (Lake Mead at historic lows). Extreme heat events increasing. Flash floods occasional. Limited traditional natural disasters
historical_context.industry_transitions: Gaming diversifying to entertainment (shows, sports, F1). Mining lithium boom emerging. Warehousing/logistics (Amazon). Technology (Tesla, data centers). Tourism evolving beyond gaming
historical_context.political_transitions: Swing state shifted Democratic 2016-2023 (presidential, state offices). Harry Reid political machine legacy. Culinary Union political power. Legislature shifted blue 2017

comparative_context.national_benchmarks: Near median income but no state income tax. Among most diverse states. Lowest educational attainment. Highest urban percentage. Worst 2008 crash, strongest recovery. Extreme housing volatility
comparative_context.unique_factors: Gaming industry political and economic dominance unique. No state income tax attracts businesses and retirees. Extreme urban concentration (94%). Water scarcity existential issue. Lithium reserves ('Saudi Arabia of lithium'). Federal land 86%. Extreme boom-bust housing cycles. Transient population (people move frequently). Entertainment industry unique labor force. 24/7 economy in Las Vegas
comparative_context.data_considerations: Las Vegas dominates (73% of population). Reno distinct economy. Rural Nevada nearly empty but huge area. Transient population makes demographics fluid. Service worker demographics differ from residents. Seasonal tourism employment. Housing data extremely volatile. Water constraints must be considered. Rapid recent change makes historical data less predictive

economic_profile.economic_trends: Steady moderate growth 2011-2023. Manufacturing resilient. Tourism strong (mountains, lakes, coast). Boston exurb benefiting. No broad-based taxes attractive. Pandemic: remote workers boosted economy
economic_profile.income_characteristics: High median income (~$90k) - among top 10 nationally. Low poverty. No state income or sales tax. Cost of living high but wages compensate. Wealthy Boston commuters
economic_profile.economic_resilience: Strong resilience. Diversified small-state economy. Weathered 2008 recession well. Pandemic: tourism hurt initially, remote work migration beneficial. Low unemployment historically

demographic_profile.population_trends: Slow growth 2011-2019 (~0.3% annually), acceleration 2020-2023 (~0.8% annually) from pandemic migration. Aging population concern
demographic_profile.migration_patterns: In-migration from Massachusetts (taxes, cost), COVID refugees from Boston. Out-migration of young to cities. Retirees moving in. Internal: southern tier (Boston suburbs) growing, North Country declining
demographic_profile.age_distribution: Aging rapidly - 2nd oldest state. Median age ~43. Large boomer population retiring. Youth outmigration for opportunities. Growing concern about workforce
demographic_profile.diversity_trends: Least diverse state: ~89% White, ~4.3% Asian, ~4% Latino, ~1.8% Black. Slowly diversifying. Refugees settling (Concord). Manchester more diverse
demographic_profile.education_levels: High educational attainment - top 10 in bachelor's degrees (~38%). Dartmouth, UNH, other colleges. But youth leave post-graduation
demographic_profile.urbanization: ~60% urban in southern tier (Manchester, Nashua). 40% rural - North Country, Lakes Region. Small state so urban/rural close together

political_context.policy_environment: Libertarian 'Live Free or Die' ethos. Fiscally conservative, socially moderate-liberal. No broad-based taxes (income or sales) - defining principle. Republican and Democratic governance alternates. Town meeting democracy tradition
key_legislation: 2011-2013: Budget challenges, right-to-work defeated, education funding debates
2013: Medicaid expansion approved
2014-2017: Minimum wage debates (keeping at federal level), heroin epidemic response
2017-2019: Education funding lawsuit, family leave programs debated, recreational marijuana debates
2021-2023: Abortion restrictions avoided, education freedom accounts (school choice), housing crisis responses, marijuana still illegal (unlike all neighbors)
political_context.housing_policy: Limited state intervention. Local control sacred. Recent attempts to encourage ADUs, density. Workforce housing law (2008) requiring towns to allow. No rent control
political_context.labor_policy: Federal minimum wage $7.25 (no state minimum). No right-to-work law. No required paid leave. Business-friendly. But worker shortage driving wage increases
political_context.social_programs: Medicaid expansion (2013). Limited social safety net otherwise. Low poverty rate reduces need. Mental health and substance abuse services priority
political_context.regulatory_environment: Light regulation. Environmental protections for lakes and mountains. Business-friendly. No sales tax enforcement complex for retailers

regional_characteristics.geography: White Mountains (north), Lakes Region (center), Seacoast (18 miles Atlantic coast), Merrimack Valley (south). Forested and mountainous
regional_characteristics.climate: Humid continental. Cold snowy winters, warm summers. Coastal areas moderated. Mountain weather extreme. Nor'easters. Leaf-peeping tourism
regional_characteristics.urban_rural_mix: 60% urban (Manchester, Nashua, Concord, Portsmouth). 40% rural - North Country, Lakes Region. Small state makes rural accessible
regional_characteristics.infrastructure: Good highways (I-93, I-95). Manchester-Boston Regional Airport. Seacoast access. Aging town roads and bridges. Limited public transit (except Boston commuter rail edge). Broadband gaps in North Country
regional_characteristics.natural_resources: Forests (timber), granite ('Granite State'), tourism (mountains, lakes, coast), maple syrup, limited agriculture

housing_context.market_characteristics: High-cost especially southern tier. Median ~$450k statewide (2023), $500k+ near Boston. Seacoast and Lakes Region expensive. North Country affordable
housing_context.affordability_trends: Steady increases 2011-2019, explosion 2020-2023. Among fastest growing housing costs nationally during pandemic. Severe shortage
housing_context.construction_trends: Chronic underbuilding. Local zoning restrictive. NIMBY resistance. Limited land near Boston. Multifamily very limited. Single-family shortages
housing_context.rental_market: ~29% renters. Extremely tight - <1% vacancy in southern tier. Rents rose 30-40% 2019-2023. Limited rental construction
housing_context.zoning_regulations: Very restrictive single-family zoning in most towns. Large lots required. Recent state efforts to encourage ADUs, workforce housing. Strong local control resistance

major_events: 2011-2013: Recovery from recession, education funding debates, Democratic legislature flip to Republican
2014-2016: Opioid/heroin epidemic declared emergency, Medicaid expansion reauthorized, presidential primary always first in nation
2017-2019: Housing shortage recognized as crisis, education funding lawsuit continues, marijuana legalization fails despite neighbor states legalizing
2020-2023: COVID refugees from Boston, housing explosion, remote work migration, workforce shortage acute, education freedom accounts (school vouchers) approved (2021)
historical_context.economic_shocks: 2008 recession impact moderate. Opioid epidemic 2014-2020. COVID-19 tourism impact. Housing shortage becoming economic development barrier
historical_context.natural_disasters: 2011 Tropical Storm Irene, nor'easters, ice storms, but generally less disaster-prone than many states. Climate change affecting winter tourism (less snow)
historical_context.industry_transitions: Traditional manufacturing declining but resilient. Tourism evolving. Remote work enabling professional services growth. Retail impacted by online (despite no sales tax advantage). Healthcare growing
historical_context.political_transitions: Swing state - governance alternates. 2011-2012 Republican, 2013-2016 Democratic governor, 2017-2024 Republican governor (Sununu). Legislature flips frequently. Presidential first primary declining influence

comparative_context.national_benchmarks: Top 10 median income. Top 10 educational attainment. Lowest poverty rate. 2nd oldest median age. Least diverse state. Among highest housing costs regionally. No broad-based taxes unique
comparative_context.unique_factors: 'Live Free or Die' libertarian culture. No income tax or sales tax (unique in region). First in nation presidential primary (tradition). Huge state legislature (400 reps, 24 senators for 1.4M people - largest in US). Town meeting democracy. Extreme aging population. Workforce shortage severe. Housing crisis for small state. Boston exurb dynamics. Lakes Region tourism. White Mountains recreation. Seacoast premium. Vermont and Maine border influences
comparative_context.data_considerations: Southern tier (Boston suburbs) vastly different from North Country. Commuters to Massachusetts significant. Second home/vacation properties in Lakes Region and Mountains distort housing data. Seasonal tourism affects employment. Small population means volatility. Aging demographics critical for planning. No sales tax creates cross-border shopping patterns. Property taxes high (fund education) affects housing costs

economic_profile.economic_trends: Steady growth 2011-2019 driven by pharma/biotech boom, financial services. Slow recovery from 2008 recession. Pandemic disrupted hospitality/retail but pharma remained strong. Post-2020: gradual recovery, tech sector growth in northern counties near NYC
economic_profile.income_characteristics: Median household income above national average ($93k), but high cost of living erodes purchasing power. Income inequality present between wealthy suburbs and urban cores
economic_profile.economic_resilience: Moderate recovery from 2008 recession due to pharma sector strength. Weathered pandemic relatively well in pharma/logistics. Vulnerable to NYC economy fluctuations

demographic_profile.population_trends: Slow steady growth 2011-2019 (~0.3% annually), slight decline 2020-2021, resumption of growth 2022-2023. First state with population density over 1,000/sq mi
demographic_profile.migration_patterns: High domestic outmigration (to PA, NC, FL) driven by high housing costs and taxes, offset by strong international immigration from India, China, Dominican Republic. Migration to eastern PA suburbs common
demographic_profile.age_distribution: Aging population, median age 40. Baby boomers driving senior population growth. Working-age population stable due to immigration
demographic_profile.diversity_trends: Highly diverse and increasingly so: White 60%, Hispanic 21%, Black 13%, Asian 10%. Strong Asian population growth. 9th-lowest non-Hispanic white percentage nationally
demographic_profile.education_levels: High educational attainment, especially in suburban counties. Strong K-12 system, major universities (Princeton, Rutgers). 40% bachelor's degree or higher
demographic_profile.urbanization: 95% urban, densest state in nation. Major cities: Newark, Jersey City, Paterson. Strong suburban character, limited rural areas

political_context.policy_environment: Moderately progressive, pro-labor, high taxes for social programs. Business-friendly regulations for pharma/finance, but stringent environmental protections
key_legislation: 2013: Medicaid expansion under ACA
2014: Pension and benefits reform
2016: Transportation funding increase (gas tax)
2019: Recreational marijuana legalization
2020: Paid family leave expansion
2020-2023: Property tax relief programs (ANCHOR)
political_context.housing_policy: Limited state intervention, local zoning control. Recent push for affordable housing mandates. Mount Laurel doctrine requiring affordable housing. No rent control except local ordinances
political_context.labor_policy: $15 minimum wage phased in by 2024, strong worker protections, prevailing wage requirements, robust unemployment insurance
political_context.social_programs: Expanded Medicaid, Pre-K expansion, property tax relief programs. Strong social safety net but funded by high taxes
political_context.regulatory_environment: Moderate to strict regulations on environment, labor. Business-friendly for certain sectors (pharma, finance). Complex permitting processes

regional_characteristics.geography: Coastal state with Atlantic beaches, Appalachian ridge, Delaware River. Urban northeast (NYC suburbs), suburban central, Pine Barrens in south, agricultural southwest
regional_characteristics.climate: Humid continental north, humid subtropical south. Hot summers, cold winters. Hurricane and flood risk on coast
regional_characteristics.urban_rural_mix: 95% urban, most densely populated state. Northern tier (NYC suburbs), central corridor (Turnpike/Parkway), shore communities, limited rural in northwest and south
regional_characteristics.infrastructure: Extensive road network (NJ Turnpike, Garden State Parkway), strong public transit (NJ Transit, PATH), major port (Port Newark), aging water infrastructure, good broadband coverage (93%)
regional_characteristics.natural_resources: Limited natural resources. Coastal tourism, agriculture in southwest (blueberries, cranberries), some quarrying

housing_context.market_characteristics: High-cost market, median home ~$565k (2025). Higher in northern/central areas, lower in southern counties. Strong suburban single-family market, growing multifamily in transit-oriented areas
housing_context.affordability_trends: Chronic affordability crisis worsening 2011-2023. Housing costs outpaced income growth. Median rent $2,500 (2024), 25% above national average. Pandemic spike 2020-2022, modest cooling 2023
housing_context.construction_trends: Underbuilding relative to demand. Transit-oriented development increasing. Multifamily construction concentrated near transit. Limited new construction in wealthy suburbs due to zoning
housing_context.rental_market: 35% renters statewide, higher in urban areas. No statewide rent control, some local ordinances. Vacancy rates very tight. 42% of renters shelter-poor (>35% income on housing)
housing_context.zoning_regulations: Historically restrictive single-family zoning dominates suburbs. Mount Laurel affordable housing mandate often resisted. Recent push for transit-oriented development zoning

major_events: 2011-2013: Slow recovery from 2008 recession, Hurricane Sandy (2012) devastates shore
2014-2016: Pension crisis debates, Atlantic City casino bankruptcies, transportation funding battles
2017-2019: Amazon HQ2 bid, marijuana legalization passed, continued property tax debates
2020-2023: COVID-19 hits hard (high density), economic recovery uneven, continued outmigration concerns
historical_context.economic_shocks: Hurricane Sandy 2012 ($70B damage), Atlantic City gaming revenue decline 2014-2016
historical_context.natural_disasters: Hurricane Sandy 2012, Hurricane Irene 2011, flooding events
historical_context.industry_transitions: Atlantic City casino decline, shift from manufacturing to pharma/logistics, tech sector growth
historical_context.political_transitions: Democratic dominance maintained 2011-2023, progressive policy expansion, pension/fiscal challenges persist

comparative_context.national_benchmarks: High median income but highest property taxes. Housing extremely expensive relative to national average. High cost of living offsets income benefits. Low poverty rate but high housing burden
comparative_context.unique_factors: Highest population density nationally. Extreme property tax burden. Strong pharma sector concentration. NYC bedroom community dynamic. Small geographic size with high diversity
comparative_context.data_considerations: Large sample sizes, but significant variation between northern (NYC-oriented), central (corridor), and southern regions. Capture commuting patterns to NYC/Philadelphia

economic_profile.economic_trends: Sluggish growth 2010-2019 (avg 1.0% annually). Oil boom 2011-2014, bust 2015-2016. Recovery 2017-2019. Strong 2021-2023 driven by energy sector resurgence. Boom-bust cycles tied to oil prices
economic_profile.income_characteristics: Low median household income ($61k, 48th nationally). High poverty rate (17.8%). Significant income inequality. Low wages outside energy/government sectors
major_employers: Federal government (Sandia, Los Alamos National Labs, military bases)
economic_profile.economic_resilience: Highly volatile due to oil price dependency. Diversification efforts slow. Federal spending provides stability. Weak recovery from 2008. Strong pandemic recovery in energy sector

demographic_profile.population_trends: Very slow growth, nearly stagnant 2011-2023 (~0.15% annually). Outmigration during oil busts, modest in-migration during booms. Population challenges persist
demographic_profile.migration_patterns: Limited in-migration. Some domestic outmigration to Texas, Colorado for opportunities. Modest international immigration, primarily from Mexico. Return migration to tribal lands
demographic_profile.age_distribution: Relatively young due to higher birth rates. Growing senior population. Median age near national average
demographic_profile.diversity_trends: Highly diverse: Hispanic/Latino 50%, White 36%, Native American 10%, Black 2%. Largest Native American population percentage. Spanish widely spoken
demographic_profile.education_levels: Low educational attainment (31.6% bachelor's or higher vs. 36.2% nationally). Improving but lags. Strong tribal colleges, UNM system. Urban-rural education gap
demographic_profile.urbanization: 77% urban, concentrated in Albuquerque metro. Rural areas include tribal lands, ranching communities. Sprawling low-density development

political_context.policy_environment: Democratic-leaning, progressive on social issues. Dependent on federal spending and oil revenue. Pro-labor in government sectors
key_legislation: 2013: Driver's licenses for undocumented immigrants
2019: Recreational marijuana legalization
2019: Tax increases on oil production to fund education
2021: Cannabis sales begin
2021-2023: Renewable energy mandates, education funding reforms
political_context.housing_policy: Limited state intervention. Affordable housing challenges in Albuquerque. Native American housing programs. No rent control
political_context.labor_policy: Prevailing wage requirements. Gradual minimum wage increases. Strong public sector unions. Right-to-work law repealed 2021
political_context.social_programs: Medicaid expansion 2014. Free college tuition program. Native American support programs. Limited social safety net relative to other states
political_context.regulatory_environment: Moderate regulations. Energy sector relatively lightly regulated. Environmental protections for federal lands. Tribal sovereignty considerations

regional_characteristics.geography: Diverse: high desert, mountains (Sangre de Cristo), plains. Rio Grande corridor. Four Corners region. Vast federal and tribal lands
regional_characteristics.climate: Arid to semi-arid, high elevation. Hot summers, cold winters in mountains. Low precipitation. Water scarcity challenges
regional_characteristics.urban_rural_mix: 77% urban (mostly Albuquerque metro, Santa Fe, Las Cruces). 23% rural (ranching, tribal lands, small towns). Very low population density
regional_characteristics.infrastructure: Limited road network outside urban areas. Aging water infrastructure. Expanding broadband but rural gaps. Major labs (Sandia, Los Alamos). Spaceport America
regional_characteristics.natural_resources: Rich oil and gas (Permian Basin), potash, copper, uranium deposits. Solar energy potential. Limited water resources

housing_context.market_characteristics: Affordable compared to national average. Median home ~$320k (2023). Higher in Santa Fe, Albuquerque metro. Very affordable rural areas. Adobe-style regional architecture
housing_context.affordability_trends: Relatively affordable 2011-2019, rapid appreciation 2020-2023 (30-40% in Albuquerque). Still affordable vs. national average. Rising costs challenging for low-income residents
housing_context.construction_trends: Modest homebuilding. Albuquerque suburban sprawl. Limited multifamily. Significant manufactured housing in rural areas. Tribal housing programs
housing_context.rental_market: 40% renters. Median rent $1,700 (2025), below national average. Tight vacancy in Albuquerque. Native American housing challenges
housing_challenges: Poverty limiting affordability despite low costs
housing_context.zoning_regulations: Permissive zoning allowing sprawl. Limited planning outside cities. Tribal land sovereignty. Few density restrictions. Historic preservation in Santa Fe

major_events: 2011-2013: Oil boom beginning, state budget challenges, Albuquerque crime concerns
2014-2016: Oil price crash, revenue shortfall, budget cuts, education funding crisis
2017-2019: Oil recovery, marijuana legalization, film industry growth, education reforms
2020-2023: Pandemic impacts, oil boom returns, federal infrastructure investments, housing price spike
historical_context.economic_shocks: 2015-2016 oil price crash, severe budget shortfalls
historical_context.natural_disasters: Severe droughts 2011-2013, 2020-2022, wildfires increasing, occasional flash floods
historical_context.industry_transitions: Oil boom-bust cycles. Film industry growth. National labs remain stable anchor. Tourism sector growth
historical_context.political_transitions: Democratic control strengthened 2018-2023, progressive policy expansion, education funding increases from oil revenue

comparative_context.national_benchmarks: Low median income, high poverty rate. Affordable housing but low wages. Educational attainment below average. Unique cultural diversity with large Native American population
comparative_context.unique_factors: Highest percentage Native American population. Major federal research facilities. Oil boom-bust economy. Trilingual culture (English, Spanish, Native languages). Tribal sovereignty complexity
comparative_context.data_considerations: Moderate sample sizes. Significant variation between Albuquerque metro and rural areas. Tribal lands may have limited data. Account for oil price cycle timing

economic_profile.economic_trends: Moderate growth 2011-2019 driven by NYC finance boom, tech (Silicon Alley). Upstate struggles with manufacturing decline. Pandemic severe hit (NYC lockdown), strong recovery 2021-2023 in finance, slower in hospitality
economic_profile.income_characteristics: Highest income inequality nationally. NYC metro median income >$80k, upstate significantly lower. Top 1% capture disproportionate income. High wages in finance/tech, low in service sectors
economic_profile.economic_resilience: Slow recovery from 2008 recession. Strong 2011-2019 growth in NYC. Severe pandemic impact but rapid recovery in finance. Upstate struggles persist. Remote work reshaping office demand

demographic_profile.population_trends: Slow growth 2011-2019, decline 2020-2022 (first in decades), resuming growth 2023. Net domestic outmigration offset by international immigration. NYC growth, upstate decline
demographic_profile.migration_patterns: Significant outmigration to Florida, North Carolina, Texas driven by high costs and taxes. Strong international immigration to NYC. Internal migration from NYC to suburbs post-pandemic
demographic_profile.age_distribution: Aging population but younger than national average due to NYC immigration. Growing senior population upstate. Median age 39
demographic_profile.diversity_trends: Highly diverse, especially NYC: White 54%, Hispanic 20%, Black 15%, Asian 9%. NYC majority-minority. Upstate whiter. Increasing Asian and Hispanic populations
demographic_profile.education_levels: High educational attainment in metro areas (NYC, Albany). World-class universities (Columbia, NYU, Cornell). 37% bachelor's or higher. Upstate-NYC education gap
demographic_profile.urbanization: 88% urban, concentrated in NYC metro. Other metros: Buffalo, Rochester, Albany, Syracuse. Rural upstate, Adirondacks, Catskills. Declining upstate cities

political_context.policy_environment: Progressive in NYC and metros, moderate upstate. High taxes to fund extensive social programs. Pro-labor, environmental regulation. NYC dominates state politics
key_legislation: 2011: Marriage equality
2014: Medicaid expansion
2016: $15 minimum wage phased in (higher in NYC)
2019: Rent regulation expansion (Housing Stability Act)
2019: Voting reforms, criminal justice reforms
2021-2023: Marijuana legalization, eviction protections, clean energy mandates
political_context.housing_policy: Strong rent control/stabilization in NYC. Housing production incentives (421-a). Affordable housing mandates. Extensive tenant protections. Upstate more market-driven
political_context.labor_policy: Strong worker protections, $15-$16 minimum wage (higher in NYC), paid family leave, strong union presence, prevailing wage requirements
political_context.social_programs: Extensive: Medicaid expansion, SNAP, housing assistance, free CUNY tuition for low-income, universal Pre-K in NYC. High-tax, high-service model
political_context.regulatory_environment: Strict environmental, labor, consumer protection regulations. Complex permitting. Business challenges with compliance costs. Financial sector relatively accommodated

regional_characteristics.geography: Diverse: Atlantic coast (Long Island), Hudson Valley, Adirondacks, Finger Lakes, Niagara Falls, Great Lakes. Major river corridors (Hudson, Mohawk)
regional_characteristics.climate: Humid continental. Hot summers, cold winters. Lake effect snow in Buffalo. Hurricane risk on coast. Climate varies significantly north to south
regional_characteristics.urban_rural_mix: 88% urban (NYC metro dominates with 60% of state population). Upstate metros declining. Rural areas in Adirondacks, Southern Tier, western NY
regional_characteristics.infrastructure: Extensive NYC metro transit (subway, commuter rail). Aging infrastructure elsewhere. Major airports (JFK, LaGuardia, Newark). Port of NY/NJ. Aging upstate infrastructure
regional_characteristics.natural_resources: Hydroelectric power (Niagara), agriculture (wine, dairy), forest products, some natural gas (fracking banned). Water resources (Catskill reservoir for NYC)

housing_context.market_characteristics: Extreme dichotomy: NYC extremely expensive (median >$700k Manhattan, >$600k Brooklyn), affordable upstate (Buffalo ~$200k). Strong rental market NYC (66% renters Manhattan)
housing_context.affordability_trends: NYC housing crisis intensified 2011-2023. Costs far outpaced income growth. Pandemic spike 2020-2022 in suburbs. NYC rents softened 2020-2021, then rebounded. Upstate affordable but declining population
housing_context.construction_trends: Significant new construction in NYC (luxury and some affordable). Upstate underbuilding. ADU reforms limited. Zoning battles in wealthy suburbs. Multifamily concentration in urban areas
housing_context.rental_market: 45% renters statewide, 66%+ in NYC. Extensive rent stabilization (~1M units NYC). Very tight vacancy rates (<3% NYC). Eviction protections strengthened 2019-2023
housing_challenges: Highest property taxes in many counties
housing_context.zoning_regulations: Very restrictive in wealthy suburbs. NYC density regulations complex. Recent reforms to allow more density near transit. Strong historical preservation. Coastal zoning restrictions

major_events: 2011-2013: Occupy Wall Street, Hurricane Sandy (2012), marriage equality, manufacturing decline upstate continues
2014-2016: Amazon NYC expansion, tech boom (Silicon Alley), fracking ban, de Blasio affordable housing plan
2017-2019: Amazon HQ2 cancelled, MTA funding crisis, criminal justice reforms, rent regulation battles
2020-2023: COVID-19 epicenter early 2020, economic shutdown, exodus to suburbs, gradual recovery, remote work transformation, homelessness crisis
historical_context.economic_shocks: Hurricane Sandy 2012, COVID-19 2020 (severe NYC impact), Amazon HQ2 cancellation 2019
historical_context.natural_disasters: Hurricane Sandy 2012, Hurricane Irene 2011, severe winters with lake effect snow
historical_context.industry_transitions: Continued upstate manufacturing decline. Tech sector boom in NYC (Silicon Alley). Media industry transformation. Tourism recovered post-pandemic
historical_context.political_transitions: Democratic dominance strengthened 2018-2023, progressive policy expansion in Albany, NYC mayor transitions (Bloomberg to de Blasio to Adams)

comparative_context.national_benchmarks: #3 GDP. Median income above national average in NYC metro, below in upstate. Highest income inequality. Extreme housing costs in NYC. High poverty rate when adjusted for cost of living
comparative_context.unique_factors: NYC financial capital dominance. Extreme economic divergence between NYC metro and upstate. Highest income inequality. Major immigration gateway. Cultural/media capital influence. Upstate economic struggles
comparative_context.data_considerations: Large sample sizes. Critical to distinguish NYC, suburban counties, and upstateessentially different economies. Capture commuting patterns, rent vs. own. Remote work shifts post-2020

economic_profile.economic_trends: Strong growth 2011-2023 (top 10 nationally). Banking boom in Charlotte. Research Triangle tech/pharma explosion. Traditional manufacturing (textiles, furniture) declined. Post-pandemic: rapid growth, migration surge
economic_profile.income_characteristics: Median income near national average ($60k). Lower income in rural areas, higher in metros. Growing middle class in metros, persistent rural poverty
economic_profile.economic_resilience: Strong recovery from 2008 recession. Banking sector stabilized post-crisis. Diverse economy weathered pandemic well. Tech sector provided stability. Rural areas struggled

demographic_profile.population_trends: Rapid growth 2011-2023 (~1.3% annually). Among fastest-growing large states. Strong domestic in-migration and births. Continued acceleration 2020-2023
demographic_profile.migration_patterns: Major destination for domestic migrants from Northeast (NY, NJ), Midwest (OH, MI), California. Retirees to coast, professionals to metros. Limited international immigration compared to peers
demographic_profile.age_distribution: Younger than national average due to in-migration and births. Growing retiree population on coast. Baby boomers to mountains/coast
demographic_profile.diversity_trends: Increasingly diverse: White 61%, Black 21%, Hispanic 10%, Asian 3%. Latino population fastest growing. Urban areas very diverse, rural areas less so
demographic_profile.education_levels: Above average and improving: strong university system (UNC, Duke, NC State). 32% bachelor's or higher. Research Triangle drives high educational attainment. Rural education gaps
demographic_profile.urbanization: 66% urban, growing rapidly. Charlotte, Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill (Research Triangle), Greensboro-Winston-Salem metros booming. Rural areas declining or stagnant

political_context.policy_environment: Swing state, Republican-controlled legislature 2011-2023 but competitive. Business-friendly, low taxes. Moderate on social issues but conservative lean. Purple state dynamics
key_legislation: 2013: Tax reform (lower rates, broader base)
2013: Medicaid NOT expanded initially (expanded 2023)
2016: HB2 'bathroom bill' controversy
2018: Voter ID requirements
2020: COVID response balancing business/health
2023: Medicaid expansion finally passed
political_context.housing_policy: Limited state intervention. Local zoning control. Charlotte loosening restrictions. Affordable housing incentives in metros. Generally pro-development
political_context.labor_policy: Right-to-work state, $7.25 federal minimum wage, limited worker protections. Business-friendly labor environment attracts employers
political_context.social_programs: Limited social safety net. Medicaid expansion delayed until 2023. Education funding debates. Growing debate over rural healthcare access
political_context.regulatory_environment: Business-friendly, light regulation compared to blue states. Environmental regulations moderate. Utilities regulated. Attracting businesses from higher-tax states

regional_characteristics.geography: Three distinct regions: Atlantic coast (Outer Banks), Piedmont (central metros), Appalachian mountains (west). Wide variety of climates and landscapes
regional_characteristics.climate: Humid subtropical. Hot summers, mild winters. Mountains colder. Hurricane risk on coast. Four distinct seasons
regional_characteristics.urban_rural_mix: 66% urban in major metros (Charlotte, Research Triangle, Greensboro-Winston-Salem). 34% rural (agriculture, small towns). Rapid suburban expansion
regional_characteristics.infrastructure: Expanding highway network, Charlotte light rail, RDU and CLT airports growing. Broadband expansion ongoing. Research Triangle Park. Military bases (Fort Bragg, Camp Lejeune)
regional_characteristics.natural_resources: Agriculture (tobacco declining, hogs, poultry), timber, phosphate, lithium. Renewable energy potential (solar growing rapidly, #4 nationally)

housing_context.market_characteristics: Rapid appreciation 2011-2023. Median home ~$350k (2023), but varies widely (Charlotte ~$400k, rural areas ~$200k). Affordable relative to coastal states attracting migration
housing_context.affordability_trends: Affordable 2011-2019, rapid appreciation 2020-2023 (40-50% in metros). Still affordable vs. Northeast/West Coast. First-time buyers challenged. Rural areas remain affordable
housing_context.construction_trends: Robust homebuilding keeping pace better than coastal states. Charlotte suburban sprawl. Research Triangle infill development. Multifamily boom in metros. Retirement community construction on coast
housing_context.rental_market: 35% renters. Growing multifamily in metros. No rent control. Healthy vacancy rates (better than coastal states but tightening). Student housing in university towns
housing_challenges: Rapid price appreciation straining longtime residents
Sprawl and traffic congestion in Charlotte
housing_context.zoning_regulations: Generally permissive allowing development. Charlotte recently liberalized further. Limited restrictive zoning compared to Northeast. Pro-growth orientation. Environmental protections on coast

major_events: 2011-2013: Recovery from recession, banking sector stabilizes, Amazon distribution centers arrive, HB2 bathroom bill
2014-2016: Panthers Super Bowl run, Research Triangle tech boom, teacher pay protests, Hurricane Matthew (2016)
2017-2019: HB2 repealed, Apple data center, Amazon fulfillment centers, continued rapid growth, housing prices rising
2020-2023: COVID-19 managed well, migration surge, housing spike, Medicaid expansion passed 2023, semiconductor plant announcements
historical_context.economic_shocks: 2008 banking crisis hit Charlotte hard, Hurricane Florence 2018, Hurricane Matthew 2016
historical_context.natural_disasters: Hurricane Florence 2018 ($24B damage), Hurricane Matthew 2016, occasional tornadoes, flooding in eastern counties
historical_context.industry_transitions: Textiles collapsed, furniture offshored, tobacco declining. Banking, tech, pharma boomed. Economic transformation from 'Old Economy' to 'New Economy' mostly successful in metros
historical_context.political_transitions: Republican control of legislature solidified 2011-2023, but governor alternated. Competitive swing state status. Growing urban-rural divide

comparative_context.national_benchmarks: #9 GDP, 9th most populous. Median income near national average. Housing more affordable than coastal states. Educational attainment improving. Among fastest-growing states
comparative_context.unique_factors: Three distinct economic regions (coast, Piedmont, mountains). Research Triangle phenomenon. Banking capital (Charlotte). Successful economic transition from textiles to tech/finance. Swing state attracting both parties' attention
comparative_context.data_considerations: Large sample sizes. Critical to distinguish Charlotte metro, Research Triangle, coastal retirement areas, and rural regionsvery different economies. Capture rapid migration patterns

economic_profile.economic_trends: Extreme boom-bust cycles. Oil boom 2011-2014 (GDP doubled). Bust 2015-2016 (oil price crash). Modest recovery 2017-2019. Boom 2021-2023. Led nation in GDP growth Q1 2023 (12.4%). Agriculture provides stability
economic_profile.income_characteristics: High per capita GDP ($75k, #7 nationally) due to oil wealth but small population. Median household income above national average during booms. Agriculture provides stable middle-class income
economic_profile.economic_resilience: Highly volatile due to oil price dependence. Agriculture provides counterbalance. Strong fiscal reserves. Weathered 2015-2016 bust. Rapid recovery capability. Limited economic diversity

demographic_profile.population_trends: Boom-bust population cycles. Rapid growth 2011-2015 (oil boom), decline 2016-2019 (bust), growth 2020-2023. #1 in net migration during booms. One of least populous states
demographic_profile.migration_patterns: Massive in-migration during oil booms from across US (Texas, California, Midwest). Out-migration during busts. Cyclical 'man camp' workers. Limited international immigration. Return to family farms during busts
demographic_profile.age_distribution: Younger than national average during booms (working-age oil workers). Aging during busts. Traditional farming communities aging. Median age rises in agricultural counties
demographic_profile.diversity_trends: Predominantly white (85%). Native American 5% (tribal lands). Small but growing minority populations during booms. Oil workers brought some diversity. Least diverse state
demographic_profile.education_levels: Moderate educational attainment (30% bachelor's or higher). Strong vocational/technical training. University of North Dakota. Agriculture extension programs. Oil boom didn't require degrees
demographic_profile.urbanization: 60% urban (concentrated in Fargo, Bismarck, Grand Forks, Minot). 40% rural (agriculture, oil patch). Extremely low density outside urban centers (9.7 people/sq mi)

political_context.policy_environment: Strongly conservative, Republican-dominated. Low taxes, light regulation. Pro-energy, pro-agriculture. Fiscal conservatism but oil revenue allows spending
key_legislation: 2011-2013: Oil boom tax policy debates, infrastructure funding for oil patch
2014-2016: Fiscal management during price crash, budget cuts
2017: Dakota Access Pipeline protests and resolution
2019: Legacy fund (oil revenue savings) debates
2021-2023: Property tax relief from oil revenue, infrastructure investments
political_context.housing_policy: Minimal state intervention. Local control. Oil boom created temporary 'man camps.' Limited affordable housing programs. Pro-development stance
political_context.labor_policy: Right-to-work state, $7.25 federal minimum wage, very light regulation. Business-friendly. Agriculture worker protections. Oil field safety regulations
political_context.social_programs: Limited social safety net. Did NOT expand Medicaid. Oil revenue allows education funding without high taxes. Strong tribal programs on reservations
political_context.regulatory_environment: Very light regulation. Pro-business, pro-energy. Environmental regulations minimal. Agriculture-friendly policies. Oil/gas regulations increased after boom for safety

regional_characteristics.geography: Great Plains, flat to rolling prairie. Missouri River corridor. Badlands in west. Bakken oil formation in northwest. Extremely flat in Red River Valley (east)
regional_characteristics.climate: Continental extremes. Very cold winters (-50F possible), hot summers. Low precipitation. Blizzards, droughts. Agriculture adapted to harsh climate
regional_characteristics.urban_rural_mix: 60% urban in four main cities (Fargo, Bismarck, Grand Forks, Minot). 40% rural (agriculture, oil patch, tribal lands). Vast unpopulated areas
regional_characteristics.infrastructure: Limited road network outside urban areas. Extensive oil field infrastructure in west. Air Force bases. Agricultural rail network. Broadband challenges in rural areas. Aging water infrastructure
regional_characteristics.natural_resources: Extremely rich: Bakken oil formation (#3 oil producing state), natural gas, lignite coal (declining), wind energy potential (#1 in wind as % of electricity), vast agricultural land

housing_context.market_characteristics: Boom-bust housing cycles. Median home ~$280k (2023). Very affordable in agricultural areas during busts. Oil patch housing shortages during booms (temporary 'man camps' erected)
housing_context.affordability_trends: Generally affordable. Spikes during oil booms (Williston housing crisis 2012-2014). Returns to affordable during busts. Among most affordable states outside boom periods
housing_context.construction_trends: Cyclical with oil prices. Rapid construction during booms (often temporary structures). Underbuilding in agricultural areas. Manufactured housing common in rural areas
housing_context.rental_market: 35% renters during normal times, higher during booms. 'Man camps' provided temporary housing. Vacancy rates swing wildly. Very affordable rents outside boom cycles
housing_challenges: Aging housing stock in agricultural towns
housing_context.zoning_regulations: Minimal zoning restrictions. Pro-development. Agriculture zoning to preserve farmland. Williston scrambled to create zoning during boom. Generally permissive

major_events: 2011-2013: Bakken oil boom explodes, GDP doubles, population surge, infrastructure strain, man camps proliferate
2014-2016: Oil price crash, bust begins, unemployment rises, out-migration, budget cuts, agricultural sector stable
2017-2019: Dakota Access Pipeline protests, gradual recovery, population stabilizes, infrastructure improvements from boom tax revenue
2020-2023: Oil boom returns, led nation in GDP growth Q1 2023 (12.4%), agriculture strong, population growth resumes, housing prices spike again
historical_context.economic_shocks: 2015-2016 oil price crash (severe), periodic agricultural droughts
historical_context.natural_disasters: Severe flooding 2011 (Minot), extreme cold events, droughts (2012, 2021), blizzards
historical_context.industry_transitions: Oil boom transformed economy 2011-2014. Coal industry declining. Wind energy sector growing. Agriculture technology advancing
historical_context.political_transitions: Republican dominance unchanged 2011-2023. Pipeline politics created national attention 2016-2017. Fiscal debates over oil revenue use

comparative_context.national_benchmarks: Low population (#47) but high per capita GDP (#7). Low unemployment during booms. Above-average median income. Affordable housing. Low poverty rate. Low educational attainment by some measures but high vocational skills
comparative_context.unique_factors: Extreme boom-bust oil economy cycles. Most dramatic GDP swings nationally. 'Man camp' phenomenon unique. Oil wealth with small population creates high per capita income. Agriculture stability counterbalances. Least diverse state. Harshest climate
comparative_context.data_considerations: Small sample sizes may limit some PUMA-level analysis. Critical to account for oil boom/bust timing affecting data. Temporary workers may not be captured. Agriculture vs. oil patch very different. Tribal lands distinct

economic_profile.economic_trends: Slow recovery from 2008 manufacturing recession. Gradual growth 2011-2019. Manufacturing restructuring (automation, high-tech). Healthcare sector growth. Post-pandemic: uneven recovery, supply chain issues affecting auto industry 2021-2023
economic_profile.income_characteristics: Median income near or slightly below national average ($62k). Wide variation: Columbus/Cleveland suburbs higher, Appalachian region lower. Rust Belt income challenges
economic_profile.economic_resilience: Slow recovery from 2008. Restructured manufacturing base more resilient. Healthcare sector provides stability. Vulnerable to auto industry cycles. Diversification efforts ongoing. Moderate pandemic impact

demographic_profile.population_trends: Very slow growth 2011-2023 (~0.2% annually). Near stagnant. Slight growth in Columbus metro, decline in Cleveland/Cincinnati suburbs, severe decline in Youngstown/Toledo. Aging population
demographic_profile.migration_patterns: Net domestic outmigration (to Sun Belt: FL, NC, TX). Brain drain of college graduates. Limited international immigration. Internal migration from declining cities to Columbus
demographic_profile.age_distribution: Aging population, above national median age. Baby boomers large cohort. Declining working-age population. Columbus younger due to university
demographic_profile.diversity_trends: Becoming more diverse but still predominantly white (79%). Black 12%, Hispanic 4%, Asian 2.5%. Urban areas diverse (Columbus, Cleveland), rural areas overwhelmingly white. Slower diversification than national trend
demographic_profile.education_levels: Moderate educational attainment (29% bachelor's or higher). Strong state university system (Ohio State, Cincinnati, others). Urban-rural education gap. Brain drain of graduates
demographic_profile.urbanization: 78% urban in metros (Columbus, Cleveland, Cincinnati, Akron, Toledo, Dayton). 22% rural (agriculture, Appalachian region). Declining legacy industrial cities

political_context.policy_environment: Competitive swing state, Republican-controlled 2011-2023 but competitive. Business-friendly, moderate regulation. Mixed on social issues. Manufacturing-focused policies
key_legislation: 2011-2013: Union collective bargaining restrictions (later repealed by referendum), Medicaid expansion
2014: Tax reform, business-friendly changes
2016-2019: Opioid crisis response, education funding reforms
2019: 'Heartbeat bill' abortion restrictions
2021-2023: Economic development incentives (Intel), energy policy debates (HB 6 scandal and repeal)
political_context.housing_policy: Limited state intervention. Local zoning control. Some affordable housing programs in cities. Foreclosure assistance programs. Pro-development stance
political_context.labor_policy: Right-to-work debate (not enacted), $10.45 minimum wage (indexed to inflation), weakened union power after 2011. Prevailing wage battles. Workforce development focus
political_context.social_programs: Medicaid expansion 2013. Moderate social safety net. Opioid treatment programs expanded. Education funding debates ongoing. Pension system challenges
political_context.regulatory_environment: Moderate regulations. Manufacturing-friendly. Environmental regulations relaxed for coal/industry. Worker safety regulations. Third-friendliest tax environment (2014 study)

regional_characteristics.geography: Diverse: Lake Erie shore (north), Appalachian foothills (southeast), flat plains (west), Ohio River valley (south). Great Lakes access. Glaciated terrain
regional_characteristics.climate: Humid continental. Hot summers, cold winters. Lake effect snow in Cleveland. Four distinct seasons. Tornado risk in western counties
regional_characteristics.urban_rural_mix: 78% urban in major metros (Columbus fastest-growing, Cleveland/Cincinnati stable, Youngstown/Toledo declining). 22% rural (agriculture in west, Appalachian in southeast)
regional_characteristics.infrastructure: Extensive highway network, aging infrastructure in legacy cities. Port of Cleveland. Major airports (CVG, CMH, CLE). Freight rail hub. Broadband expansion needed in rural areas
regional_characteristics.natural_resources: Agriculture (corn, soybeans), coal (declining), shale gas (Utica formation), limestone, salt. Manufacturing legacy infrastructure

housing_context.market_characteristics: Very affordable compared to coasts. Median home ~$220k (2023). Columbus appreciating, Cleveland/Cincinnati stable, legacy cities declining (Youngstown, Dayton). Wide variation across state
housing_context.affordability_trends: Generally affordable 2011-2019, modest appreciation 2020-2023 in Columbus/Cincinnati. Still very affordable nationally. Legacy cities have extremely cheap housing. First-time buyers have opportunities
housing_context.construction_trends: Modest new construction concentrated in Columbus suburbs. Limited building in declining cities. Significant housing abandonment in Youngstown, Toledo. Infill development in urban cores
housing_context.rental_market: 32% renters. Healthy vacancy rates. Affordable rents. University towns have student housing demand. No rent control. Some gentrification in Columbus/Cleveland urban cores
housing_challenges: Aging housing stock in legacy cities
housing_context.zoning_regulations: Permissive in most areas. Legacy cities trying to manage decline. Columbus suburbs seeing restrictive zoning debates. Generally pro-development. Historic preservation in some urban neighborhoods

major_events: 2011-2013: Slow recovery from 2008 manufacturing recession, collective bargaining referendum, Medicaid expansion decision
2014-2016: Opioid crisis intensifies, tax reform, Republican presidential politics (swing state focus), manufacturing automation increases
2017-2019: Intel site selection process, HB 6 energy scandal, opioid litigation, Browns/Cavs sports moments, continued urban decline in legacy cities
2020-2023: COVID-19, auto industry supply chain crisis, Intel fab plant announced (major win), JobsOhio recruitment efforts, abortion politics post-Dobbs
historical_context.economic_shocks: Opioid epidemic economic impacts 2014-2020, COVID-19 manufacturing disruptions, 2008 recession lingering effects
historical_context.natural_disasters: Tornado outbreaks occasionally, Lake Erie flooding, severe winters
historical_context.industry_transitions: Manufacturing automation eliminating jobs. Auto industry restructuring. Coal decline. Healthcare sector expansion. Tech sector growth in Columbus. Aerospace concentration in Dayton
historical_context.political_transitions: Swing state dynamics, Republican control strengthened 2011-2023 but competitive. Kasich to DeWine governors. Congressional delegation competitive

comparative_context.national_benchmarks: #7 GDP (large economy) but #34 per capita. Median income near national average. Very affordable housing. Moderate poverty rate. Educational attainment slightly below average. Slow population growth
peer_states: Pennsylvania (similar size, Rust Belt, swing state)
comparative_context.unique_factors: Quintessential swing state politically. Rust Belt transformation ongoing. Diverse regional economies (Columbus growing, Cleveland stable, Youngstown declining). Auto industry concentration. 'Brain drain' to Sun Belt. Opioid crisis epicenter. Manufacturing to service transition
comparative_context.data_considerations: Large sample sizes. Critical to distinguish Columbus (growth), Cleveland/Cincinnati (stable), legacy cities (decline), and Appalachian region (poverty). Manufacturing job quality changes over time. Political competitiveness affects policies

economic_profile.economic_trends: Boom-bust cycles tied to oil prices. Boom 2011-2014, severe bust 2015-2016, recovery 2017-2019, boom 2021-2023. Agriculture provides stability. Aerospace sector growing. Wind energy expansion
economic_profile.income_characteristics: Median household income below national average ($56k, 42nd nationally). Low cost of living improves purchasing power. Rural poverty significant. Energy sector creates high-wage jobs during booms
economic_profile.economic_resilience: Highly volatile due to oil dependence. 2015-2016 bust devastated state budget. Agriculture provides counterbalance. Aerospace sector stable. Diversification efforts ongoing but slow

demographic_profile.population_trends: Moderate growth 2011-2023 (~0.8% annually). Growth during oil booms, stagnation during busts. Steady rural to urban migration internally
demographic_profile.migration_patterns: Modest domestic in-migration from Texas, California during booms. Out-migration during busts to Texas. Limited international immigration. Strong Native American population (39 tribal nations)
demographic_profile.age_distribution: Younger than national average due to higher birth rates. Growing senior population. Median age slightly below national
demographic_profile.diversity_trends: Diverse: White 65%, Native American 9% (second-highest % nationally), Hispanic 11%, Black 7%, Asian 2.5%. Growing Hispanic population. Large tribal presence unique
demographic_profile.education_levels: Below national average (26% bachelor's or higher). Improving in metros. Strong vocational/technical training. Oklahoma State, University of Oklahoma. Rural education challenges
demographic_profile.urbanization: 66% urban in Oklahoma City and Tulsa metros. 34% rural (agriculture, tribal lands, small towns). Suburban sprawl in OKC

political_context.policy_environment: Strongly conservative, Republican-dominated. Low taxes, light regulation. Pro-energy, pro-agriculture. Tribal sovereignty considerations. Fiscal conservatism but oil revenue volatility
key_legislation: 2011-2013: Tax cuts funded by oil boom
2015-2016: Budget crisis from oil bust, deep education cuts
2018: Teacher walkout over education funding, Medicaid expansion rejected
2020: McGirt v. Oklahoma Supreme Court ruling (tribal jurisdiction)
2021-2023: Tax cuts, abortion restrictions, education funding restored partially
political_context.housing_policy: Minimal state intervention. Local control. Pro-development. Limited affordable housing programs. Tribal housing on reservations
political_context.labor_policy: Right-to-work state, $7.25 federal minimum wage, very light regulation. Business-friendly. Energy sector worker safety focus
political_context.social_programs: Very limited social safety net. Did NOT expand Medicaid initially (voters approved 2020 via ballot). Low education funding. Tribal programs on reservations
political_context.regulatory_environment: Very light regulation. Pro-business, pro-energy. Environmental regulations minimal. Earthquake regulations after fracking-induced seismicity 2014-2016

regional_characteristics.geography: Diverse: Great Plains (west), Ozark Plateau (northeast), Ouachita Mountains (southeast), Red River valley (south). Tornado Alley. Numerous tribal lands
regional_characteristics.climate: Continental extremes. Hot summers, cold winters. Severe weather: tornadoes (#1 risk nationally), ice storms, droughts, flash floods. Volatile climate
regional_characteristics.urban_rural_mix: 66% urban in OKC and Tulsa metros. 34% rural (ranching, agriculture, tribal lands, oil patch). Low density outside metros
regional_characteristics.infrastructure: Highway-dependent. Tinker AFB major installation. Oil/gas pipeline network extensive. Broadband challenges in rural areas. Aging infrastructure in small towns. Tribal infrastructure separate
regional_characteristics.natural_resources: Rich oil and gas reserves, wind energy (#2 in wind energy % of electricity), natural gas, agriculture (cattle, wheat, cotton), gypsum, limestone

housing_context.market_characteristics: Very affordable. Median home ~$200k (2023). OKC and Tulsa affordable for metros. Rural areas extremely cheap. Sprawling low-density development
housing_context.affordability_trends: Consistently affordable 2011-2019, modest appreciation 2020-2023 (20-30% in metros). Still very affordable nationally. Homeownership highly attainable
housing_context.construction_trends: Steady suburban homebuilding in OKC, Tulsa. Master-planned communities. Limited multifamily outside metros. Manufactured housing common in rural areas. Tornado-resistant construction improving
housing_context.rental_market: 30% renters. Very affordable rents. Healthy vacancy rates. Limited luxury rental market. University town rental demand (Norman, Stillwater)
housing_challenges: Aging housing stock in small towns
housing_context.zoning_regulations: Very permissive zoning allowing sprawl. Limited planning outside cities. Pro-development orientation. Few density restrictions. Tornado shelter requirements

major_events: 2011-2013: Oil boom, tax revenue surge, budget expansion, fracking expansion
2014-2016: Oil price crash, severe budget crisis, education funding cuts, fracking-induced earthquakes increase dramatically, teacher shortages worsen
2017-2019: Teacher walkout 2018 (national attention), moderate oil recovery, continued budget challenges, earthquakes decline after regulation
2020-2023: COVID-19, voters approve Medicaid expansion (June 2020), McGirt ruling creates legal complexity, oil boom returns, housing prices spike modestly
historical_context.economic_shocks: 2015-2016 oil price crash (severe budget crisis), fracking-induced earthquakes 2014-2016
historical_context.natural_disasters: Major tornadoes regularly (Moore 2013, El Reno 2013), ice storms, droughts, flooding. Fracking-induced earthquakes 2014-2016
historical_context.industry_transitions: Oil/gas automation reducing jobs. Wind energy sector growing rapidly. Aerospace sector expanding. Agriculture mechanization
historical_context.political_transitions: Republican dominance solidified 2011-2023. Teacher walkout created rare bipartisan education focus 2018. Tribal jurisdiction expanded via McGirt 2020

comparative_context.national_benchmarks: Below-average median income but very low cost of living. Low educational attainment. Very affordable housing. High poverty rate in rural areas. Second-highest Native American population %
comparative_context.unique_factors: Tornado Alley location. Fracking-induced earthquake crisis 2014-2016. 39 tribal nations (second-most federally recognized tribes). McGirt Supreme Court ruling creates unique legal complexity. Extreme oil price volatility impacts. Teacher shortage crisis gained national attention
comparative_context.data_considerations: Moderate sample sizes. Distinguish OKC/Tulsa metros vs. rural areas. Tribal lands have separate data/sovereignty. Account for oil boom/bust timing. Earthquake insurance costs affecting housing. Teacher walkout period unique

economic_profile.economic_trends: Strong growth 2011-2019 driven by tech boom (Portland), Nike expansion, wine industry. Timber industry continued long decline. Post-pandemic: remote work influx, housing spike, uneven urban/rural recovery
economic_profile.income_characteristics: Median household income slightly above national average ($76k). Portland metro higher, rural areas lower. Income inequality growing. Tech workers vs. service workers wage gap
economic_profile.economic_resilience: Strong recovery from 2008 recession aided by tech sector. Diversified economy more resilient than timber-dependent past. Pandemic: tech thrived, hospitality struggled. Remote work influx 2020-2023

demographic_profile.population_trends: Steady growth 2011-2019 (~1.0% annually), accelerated 2020-2023 due to remote work migration from California. Portland metro driving growth, rural areas stagnant or declining
demographic_profile.migration_patterns: Strong domestic in-migration from California (housing refugees). Some outmigration to Idaho, Washington. Internal migration from rural to urban. Limited international immigration compared to peers
demographic_profile.age_distribution: Younger than national average in Portland, older in rural areas. Baby boomers to coast/rural areas. Millennials to Portland. Median age near national average
demographic_profile.diversity_trends: Predominantly white (75%) but diversifying. Hispanic 13%, Asian 5%, Black 2%, Native American 1%. Portland metro more diverse. Rural areas overwhelmingly white. Increasing Hispanic population in agriculture areas
demographic_profile.education_levels: Above national average (35% bachelor's or higher). Strong universities (U of Oregon, Oregon State, Portland State). Portland very educated. Rural education challenges
demographic_profile.urbanization: 81% urban, concentrated in Portland metro (60% of state), Eugene, Salem. 19% rural (timber towns, agriculture, coastal communities). Sharp urban-rural divide

political_context.policy_environment: Progressive in urban areas (Portland), conservative in rural areas. No sales tax (unique). Progressive social policies, environmental leadership. Deep urban-rural political divide
key_legislation: 2011-2013: Medicaid expansion under ACA
2014: Marijuana legalization approved by voters
2015: Paid sick leave, clean fuels program
2019: Rent control (statewide first-in-nation), climate legislation attempts
2020-2023: Drug decriminalization (Measure 110), homeless crisis response, wildfire recovery
political_context.housing_policy: Statewide rent control enacted 2019 (first in nation). Urban growth boundaries (Portland). Upzoning efforts in cities. ADU reforms. Strong tenant protections. Homeless crisis driving policy
political_context.labor_policy: $14.70 minimum wage (higher in Portland metro), strong worker protections, paid family leave, robust unemployment insurance. No sales tax affects revenue
political_context.social_programs: Medicaid expansion, drug decriminalization experiment 2020-2023 (Measure 110), homeless services expansion, mental health initiatives
political_context.regulatory_environment: Strong environmental regulations (urban growth boundaries, clean energy mandates, timber harvest restrictions). Labor protections robust. Business challenges with compliance costs but no sales tax attracts some

regional_characteristics.geography: Diverse: Pacific coast (temperate rainforest), Cascade Range (volcanic mountains), Willamette Valley (population/agriculture center), high desert east of Cascades. Columbia River Gorge
regional_characteristics.climate: West of Cascades: oceanic, wet winters, dry summers. East of Cascades: semi-arid, continental extremes. Wildfire risk increasing. Earthquake/tsunami risk on coast
regional_characteristics.urban_rural_mix: 81% urban in Portland metro, Eugene, Salem, Bend. 19% rural (timber towns declining, agriculture, coastal communities, high desert ranching). Extreme urban-rural political divide
regional_characteristics.infrastructure: Portland MAX light rail, limited public transit elsewhere. I-5 corridor critical. Ports (Portland). Tech infrastructure strong. Broadband gaps in rural areas. Aging bridges. Wildfire infrastructure concerns
regional_characteristics.natural_resources: Timber (strictly regulated), hydroelectric power (extensive), agriculture (wine, hazelnuts, berries), fishing (salmon), geothermal potential. Water abundant west of Cascades

housing_context.market_characteristics: Expensive in Portland metro (median ~$550k), affordable in rural areas (~$300k). Bend very expensive resort market. Sharp urban-rural divide. Strong demand from California migrants
housing_context.affordability_trends: Rapid appreciation 2011-2019 in Portland (60%+), accelerated 2020-2023 (30% more). California migration driving prices. Statewide rent control enacted 2019 to address crisis. Affordability crisis in cities
housing_context.construction_trends: Underbuilding relative to demand in Portland. Urban growth boundaries limit sprawl. Infill development increasing. ADU boom post-reforms. Limited rural construction. Multifamily increasing in cities
housing_context.rental_market: 40% renters in Portland. Statewide rent control (7% + inflation annual cap) enacted 2019 - first in nation. Tight vacancy rates (<5% Portland). Homeless crisis visible
housing_context.zoning_regulations: Urban growth boundaries limit sprawl. Portland loosening single-family zoning (allowing duplexes citywide). ADU reforms statewide. Strong environmental review. Slow permitting processes

major_events: 2011-2013: Economic recovery, tech growth, marijuana legalization campaign, no sales tax remains
2014-2016: Marijuana legalization implemented, housing crisis emerging, Bundy standoff (Malheur 2016), tech boom continues
2017-2019: Statewide rent control enacted (first in nation), homeless crisis worsens, Portland protests, climate legislation attempts fail
2020-2023: COVID-19, Portland protests (George Floyd), wildfires devastate rural areas (2020), drug decriminalization experiment (Measure 110), California exodus influx, housing spike
historical_context.economic_shocks: 2020 wildfires ($500M+ damage), timber industry collapse 1990s-ongoing
historical_context.natural_disasters: Catastrophic wildfires 2020 (Labor Day fires), regular wildfire seasons, Cascadia Subduction Zone earthquake risk, occasional flooding
